html: 10.24.17  9:53 pm   Bill, this is someome different from 10.24.17  7:17 pm , but common taken a break! Do it for us and for you, even though the 6 days will be more difficult, still! But we don't know your schedule, you know what's best for you. But just do it. Do it for yourself. But if the end game is not good then don't do it. But do it in the near future.

10.24.17  8:17 pm   10.23.17  7:22 pm Don't ever feel bad about not having perfect pitch. Perfect pitch sounds all well and good and has a nice name, but it's just a tool.

      And for me, it's a tool that I don't really use a lot anymore. It was helpful when I was transcribing lots of stuff, but people with good relative pitch can do it at essentially the same speed. The same goes for anything else someone with perfect pitch can do. In my opinion and in my experience, people who brag about perfect pitch are really insecure.

      Anyway Bill, my question is: Do you like making longer and stronger videos, or do you want to go back to making vine-sized videos?

      I know you've talked about how they're not really feasible on youtube because of the algorithm.

     Please use capital letters.

i do

10.18.17  2:46 am   10.16.17  11:09 pm why not get the kind that has the long eraser that you can twist out as it wears down and replace when it runs out? even if you got a new one each time it would last a lot longer than one with a tiny unreplaceable nub. usually they come with extra erasers (and lead) in the pack. they cost more but it would probably end up the same or less as the amount of pencils you would go through in the same length of time. it likely makes little difference but maybe you might want to try and see if you like it

10.16.17  9:04 pm   Question for Bill Wurtz on 10.1.17 4:23 pm : "define random."

Bill says chosen without reason blah blah preferably by computer to eliminate accidental reasoning

I feel the particular response to be inadequate due to some research

"One thing that traditional computer systems aren't good at is coin flipping," says Steve Ward, Professor of Computer Science and Engineering at MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory. "They're deterministic, which means that if you ask the same question you'll get the same answer every time. In fact, such machines are specifically and carefully programmed to eliminate randomness in results. They do this by following rules and relying on algorithms when they compute."

You can program a machine to generate what can be called "random" numbers, but the machine is always at the mercy of its programming. "On a completely det erminist ic machine you can't generate anything you could really call a random sequence of numbers," says Ward, "because the machine is following the same algorithm to generate them. Typically, that means it starts with a common 'seed' number and then follows a pattern." The results may be sufficiently complex to make the pattern difficult to identify, but because it is ruled by a carefully defined and consistently repeated algorithm, the numbers it produces are not truly random. "They are what we call 'pseudo-random' numbers," Ward says.

- MIT School of Engineering

How do you feel about this? Will you stay with your stance of preferring computers to eliminate accidental reasoning or have you been influenced to believe that the machine can never trump human creativity

10.6.17  9:54 pm   10.6.17  6:18 pm   Not to be argumentative or anything... you obviously know your situation better than I do... but maybe people want to work with you because they really dig what you're doing, and not because they just want to get publicity out of it? Although, I'm sure you get things on both sides of the spectrum with this. The whole "collab" thing has become very fake, like 2 people pretending to be friends, who really don't know each other at all, doing a video together only because their managers or promoters or whoever arranged it for them. Then they'll beat the dead horse of doing some kind of 'challenge vid' or some other over-done concept just for the sake of advertising eachother's channels to the other person's fan base... I'm not saying I think you should feel pressured or obligated to collaborate with other people or anything like that, but maybe it's kind of an over-generalizatio n to say that other people are only interested in working with you for publicity's sake?

     Like, man, if I lived in NY I'd be emailing you all the time to try to convince you to get together and jam with me hahaha... I wouldn't want it to be recorded or put up on the internet. I'd just love to play music with you.

10.6.17  4:49 pm   I can relate to what you are saying... But I can compromise. People will not be the way you want them too, all the time, along with your dreams and vision. It can be very revealing to be close with people that you share (apparently) little things with, in my experience, and my feelings and constant wanting for people to come aboard and sail on my artistic boat (or boat fleet) slowly started to become not so meaningful. I'm a full time musician and one of my best and closest friends is a physics doctor; my girlfriend is an actress. It is all so wonderful. Please don't miss out and don't be afraid. (I'm not the one you responded to in 10.6.17  4:59 am , btw).
